title: Topological Atlas: Mapping Contemporary Borderscapes
descriptions:
The "Topological Atlas: Mapping Contemporary Borderscapes" grant proposal aims to develop a transdisciplinary research program focused on mapping, analyzing, and intervening in the porous, shifting, and solidified nature of contemporary borders. The project will utilize a digital atlas as a medium to explore the concept of borders as topological entities, challenging traditional cartographic norms.

Through the use of digital technologies, GIS technology, and Google Earth, the research will employ a Topological Atlas approach to create visual counter-geographies that represent the experiences of individuals encountering borders. By engaging in participative and co-produced research forms, the project seeks to understand the mobility of geopolitical territorial formations, the operation beyond legal frameworks, and the variable enforcement of treaties in border areas.

The main research question driving this project is: "How can mapping be used to represent borders as topological entities through the experience of those who encounter them?" By focusing on the relationship between academic inquiry, knowledge production, and the impact of knowledge, this proposal aims to disrupt traditional cartographic norms and provide a unique perspective on contemporary borderscapes. Ultimately, the project will contribute to a better understanding of the complexities and challenges associated with borders in the modern world.
